SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A METHOD OF ORIENTATION TO THE PERSON

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experience as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience, but others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving them blank. You are invited to give detailed or descriptive particulars where necessary.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Think Is Still Being Circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MEETING OF EXPLORATION TO THE WESTERN PROVINCE

SUBJECT: THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer experiences because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experience as another. Some of the questions have not been answered by everyone, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answering them in detail; or describing particular events.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1930, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whatever their residence at present.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Pioneers That Did" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2 entitled "Pioneers Who Will Be Prepared at a Later Date." Some of these will be distributed, but others will be prepared at a later date. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

PRESENTATION OF QUESTIONNAIRES

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's collection at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

"There didn't appear to be much in the East at that time you a young man. The West was growing up for settlers at that time. The pioneer farming offered g the wonderful opportunity in the West."

1. Your full name: CHARLES AVERY

2. Your address: WHITE BEAR, P.C., SASK.

3. Date: MAR. 19, 1944

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BRUSSELS, ONTARIO

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MARCH 26, 1918

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   no other

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use 1, which is a small child):

   I was 18 years old.

9. What was your occupation then?

   There didn't appear to be much in the East at that time for a young man. The West was opening up for settlers at this time. The pioneer spirit flourished and the wonderful opportunity in the West.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Through other people who had come back, as well as some circulars.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They approved! Had very little comment.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railroad. Car 9 immigrant effect including 16 head of horses. Also were in pursuit of Mr. Smith.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other events.)

There were about 30 cars in the train, made up of 12-14 cars with a poorly numbered 9 non-paying passengers who al-time showed considerable difficulty in avoiding R.R. officials. They were two hours delayed in the difficult area, with its continuous hills and curves and best William. Train was divided at Winnipeg. Cars for 8 hours in the rain and snow. Very cold. Train was divided at Brandon. Hours and 1/2 hour time at Edmonton. When a few more cars were added from the north from Goose Bay. You were a real children of Britain and all you asked was plenty.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With a cousin at Millarville

16. Where did you settle or take up land? N.W. Survey Current - T. 32 R. 16 W. 3 d.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

ROBERTON AND WHITE BEAR.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Factory worker and tried for farm work.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

were awestruck! Had very little comment.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad. Car 9 immigrant effect including 16 heady horses. Also were in property g.

14. What incidents of the journey? Adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.

There were about 30 cars in the train made up of immigrants with a fairly number of men paying passengers who al-though considerably injured in escaping M.R. officials. They were thrown considerably off course with it going through the train cars held up and down a steep embankment. Later the cars were loaded at the bottom of the embankment and sent to Brandon, Manitoba and a few more cars were added from there. The train was finally from June 25th when a few more cars were added at Edmonton and a few cars were added at Saskatoon.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With a cousin at Millarville

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

N.W. Survey Section 7 R. 32 R. 16 W 3

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

ROBERTON AND WHITE BEAR.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Factory worker and tried for farm work.

ELIZABETH MARIE CLARK

JUNE 18, 1918

SWIFT CURRENT, SASK.

NOT TO MY KNOWLEDGE.

MORE OTHERS.

HEAVY FARMER HANGING UP ON THE BULLFROG TRAIL WITH HORSE AND WAGON OF 20 CLOTHES IN THE MIDDLE OF THE PRAIRIE RAIN THE NIGHT AS ALONG THE WHOLE 9-MILE WAGGER HAD TO BE CLAIMED FOR A BROKEN IN JUNE 1919.

VERY FUNNY ADVICE IN THE OFFICIAL OF THE 20'S! I AM TOLD THAT YOU HAVE TO DRIVE AND CLOUD HEAD IN MARSHLANDS FOR WHEN IMMEDIATELY THOUGHT TO SAY "READY FOR TRAVEL."

GO TO THE WEST LUNCH, NO MORE COOK.
